At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
In the past, there was a great king in a large country named Longevity;
The king had a prince named Long Life.
The king governed the country with righteousness, and the people were not harmed by weapons or staffs. The wind and rain were timely, and the five grains were abundant.
The king of a neighboring country governed with violence and did not practice proper governance. The people of the country were poor and destitute. He said to his ministers:
I have heard that the country of King Longevity is not far from here, prosperous and wealthy, but without any military preparations.
I want to go there to attack and take his country. Is it possible to succeed?
The ministers replied:
Very good!
They then raised an army and went to the borders of King Longevity's country.
The officials and people of the border reported to the king, saying:
'That greedy king has raised troops and is coming, wanting to attack King Ming's country. We only ask that you prepare in advance.'
King Changshou summoned his ministers and said to them:
'The reason he is coming is just because he covets my country's people, granaries, grains, treasures, and jewels.
If we fight with him, we will certainly injure our people.
I will not fight over a country and kill my people.'
The ministers said:
'We all understand the methods of warfare and can certainly defeat him, preventing King Ming's troops from being invaded by him.'
The king said:
'If I defeat him, there will be deaths and injuries.
Both his troops and my people value their lives. I love them and harm him. The wise do not do this.'
The ministers did not listen. They kept the king in the palace and themselves went out to the border to meet and resist him.
King Changshou then said to his crown prince:
'He covets my country, so he comes to attack me.
Now the ministers, because of me, want to resist him.
When two enemies face each other, there will surely be casualties. Now I want to entrust the country to you and leave together.'
The crown prince said:
'Yes.'
Then the father and son together scaled the city wall and left, hiding in the mountains.
Then the greedy king entered his country and offered a reward of a thousand ounces of gold and ten million coins for information on King Changshou.
One day, King Changshou came out and sat under a tree by the roadside.
A brahmin from a distant place also rested under the tree.
He asked King Changshou:
'Where are you from?
Why are you here?'
The king said:
'I am a person from this country. I happened to come here to play.'
King Changshou asked the brahmin:
'Wise one, where do you come from?
Where do you wish to go?
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:

I am a poor and humble wayfarer from a distant country. I have heard from afar that the Long-lived King of this country delights in giving generously and providing for the poor and weak. I have come from afar, wishing to beg for alms to sustain myself.
I do not know what the king's intentions are now.
You are a person of this country, have you heard what his intentions are now?
Are you willing to give generously or not?
The king silently thought to himself:
He has come from afar for my sake, but he has encountered my loss of the country and will leave empty-handed without obtaining anything.
This is truly pitiful.
Then, the king shed tears and said to the brÄhmaá¹‡a:
I am the Long-lived King.
There was a king from another country who came and attacked me. I lost the country and went into hiding here.
Now I have heard that you have come to return to me, but I am empty and destitute and have nothing to offer you. What can I do?
The two faced each other, sobbing and crying.
The king said:
I have heard that the new king admires me very much. If you take my head to him, you can get a great reward.
The brÄhman said:
I have heard from afar that the great king universally saves all. I came to beg, hoping to get a little to sustain my remaining life.
But now that the king has lost his country, I consider myself to be of little merit. Now I am told to cut off my head, I dare not accept the order.
The king said:
You have come from afar wanting to get something, but you have met me in a difficult situation, and I am unable to fulfill your wishes.
Moreover, all people in the world will eventually die. We are about to die. I wish to give you my body as a favor. Why do you hesitate?
If you do not take it now, there will be others coming later, and I will still give it to them. It is better to take it early.
The brÄhman said:
I cannot bear to kill the great king.
Great king, if you have a mind of great compassion and must sacrifice your life to show kindness and generosity, then just let go of your hands and follow me.
The king then followed him out of the city gate and ordered him to be bound and taken to King Greed.
The king immediately paid the brahmin the reward of gold coins and sent him away.
King Greed then had people burn King Longevity to death at the crossroads.
The king's former ministers said to King Greed:
'This was our former lord, who is now to be executed for his crimes. We wish to provide some meager provisions to see him off.'
King Greed granted permission.
The ministers prepared food and wept over him. The people who watched all said:
'The king is unjustly killed.'
The villages and countryside all cried out to heaven.

When Prince Changsheng was born, he came out on the side of the road and heard people talking. He knew that his father had been captured by a greedy king, so he pretended to carry firewood and went out to sell it in the bustling market.
He stood in front of his father, watching as his father was about to be executed, and his heart was filled with grief.
His father saw Changsheng and feared that he would be angry and seek revenge on his behalf. His father then sighed to the heavens, saying:
'As a son, you should be utmost filial, not letting your father die with resentment.
Do not seek revenge on your father's behalf. Your father would rather die happily than be worried.
If you disobey your father's words and kill others, it would mean your father dies with lingering resentment.'
Changsheng could not bear to watch his father's execution, so he returned to the mountains. King Changshou was then executed by burning.
Changsheng thought to himself after a long time:
'My father was deeply righteous and sincere, even to the point of death he did not waver;
Yet this King Greed is unreasonable, not distinguishing good from evil, and unjustly killed my father.
Although my father had a compassionate and benevolent heart, he died without anger;
But I cannot bear it. If I do not kill this King Greed, I will never live in this world for long.'
So he went out to work as a laborer.
In the market, a minister of the state hired a gardener and obtained Changsheng.
He made him plant vegetables, and the vegetables were very good.
The next day, the minister inspected the garden and saw that the vegetables were very good. He called out and asked the gardener.
The gardener replied:
'Previously, I hired a person to do it, so it is as good as this.'
The minister then called Changsheng and, seeing him, asked:
'Can you cook food?'
He replied:
'I can cook.'
He cooked food that was very delicious, and so he was invited to the king.
The king went to inspect the meal, and the food and drink were delicious. He then asked:
Who cooked this meal?
The ministers replied:
We previously hired a person who can cook this meal.
The king then summoned him and took him back to the palace to make food and drink.
On another day, the king asked Changsheng:
Have you learned military skills yet?
He replied:
I have indeed learned them.
The king then took him and placed him by his side, and said to him:
I have an enemy, who is the son of the king of Changshou.
I am always afraid that he will suddenly encounter me while I am coming and going. Now I rely on you, and I hope you will help me prepare for this.
Changsheng replied:
Yes, I will do my utmost to serve the king.
On another day, the king asked Changsheng:
Do you like hunting?
He replied:
I liked hunting when I was young.
The king then ordered the preparation of the carriage outside and went out hunting with Changsheng.
As soon as they entered the mountain forest, they saw running beasts. The king and Changsheng chased after them, turning into the deep mountains, confused and lost their way, unable to get out.
Confused for three days, they eventually became hungry and exhausted. The king then dismounted, untied his sword, and handed it to Changsheng, saying:
I am very tired. You sit, and I want to lie down with my head on your lap.
Changsheng said:
Yes.
The king then fell asleep.
Changsheng thought to himself:
From before, I have been seeking an opportunity to kill the greedy king. Today, I have obtained what I wished for.
He then drew his sword, wanting to kill King Tan.
He thought:
When my father was dying, he entrusted me with his earnest request. How can I indulge my foolish intentions and disobey my kind father's dying instructions?
He then sheathed his sword and stopped.
The king then woke up in surprise and asked Changsheng:
'I dreamt that Prince Changshou wanted to come and kill me, and I was greatly frightened.
Why is this so?'
Changsheng said:
'There are powerful ghosts and spirits in this mountain, and they came to frighten Your Majesty because they saw you here.
I will serve and guard you myself. Your Majesty should rest at ease and have no fear.'
The king was able to lie down again, but Changsheng drew his sword and wanted to kill him. Thinking of his father's words, he stopped again.
The king woke up again in fright and said to Changsheng:
'I again dreamt that Prince Changshou wanted to come and kill me, and I was greatly afraid of him.
Why is this so?'
Changsheng said:
'It is the doing of the mountain spirits.
Your Majesty has nothing to fear.'

The king lay down again, and Changsheng drew his sword and wanted to kill him. Thinking of his father's words, he stopped again. He finally threw the sword to the ground, and had no further intention of killing the king.
The king was startled awake and told Changsheng:
I had another dream in which the Prince of Longshou said:ğŸ”½'Spare me.
Do not kill me again.'
Thereupon Changsheng said:
I am indeed the Prince of Longshou, Changsheng. I truly came out to kill the great king in order to avenge my father's enmity.
I thought of how my father, when he was dying, earnestly entrusted me not to seek revenge;
yet I, being foolish, wanted to disobey my father's words. Carefully contemplating my father's teachings, which were earnest and sincere, I did not dare disobey them.
Therefore, I now throw my sword to the ground, in order to follow my father's words.
Even so, I am still afraid that someday I will be confused and lose my bearings, and thus disobey my deceased father's teachings.
I now therefore inform you myself. I wish that the great king will immediately execute my body, quickly destroy this evil intention, and cause it to be completely severed from beginning to end.
The king then repented and said:

'I am a violent criminal who does not distinguish between good and evil. The wise father and son practiced benevolence to the utmost, even to the point of death, but I was greedy and cruel and did not realize it at all.
Today is like this, and my life is in the hands of my son.
My son still harbors benevolence, only remembering his father's words and not harming each other. It is truly a thick blessing.
I now want to return to the country, by which path should I go?'
Changsheng said:
'I know the shortcut I took before, but I was confused and wanted to avenge my father.'
Changsheng then left the forest with the king, and saw the group of ministers scattered all over the edge of the forest.
The king then stopped to sit and prepared food and drink.
The king asked the ministers:
'Do you recognize Prince Changsheng of Changshou?'
Some who did not recognize him replied:
'We do not recognize him.'
Some who did recognize him, having received favors from Changsheng in the past, feared the king would kill them, and also said:
'We do not recognize him.'
The king then pointed and said:
This is Changsheng.
The king said:
From today onwards, I will return my former country to you. I wish to return this country to the prince;
From today onwards, you will be my younger brother. If there are other countries that come to invade and seize, you should help each other.
The king then led his ministers and soldiers back to his original country, and the countries exchanged rare treasures as gifts.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The king of long life at that time is now me;

The greedy king is Devadatta.
Devadatta and I have had enmity for lifetimes. Although I have had good intentions towards him, he still wanted to harm me.

The bodhisattva's pursuit of the Way was as difficult as this. Even when he saw the harm done by thieves, he had no resentment in his heart. Therefore, he attained Buddhahood and became the Honored One of the Three Realms.
The bhiká¹£us rejoiced and bowed to the Buddha.
The Buddha is the captain of the ocean ship, using the Dharma bridge to ferry across the river.
The vehicle of the MahÄyÄna path delivers all gods and humans.
It is also said that one unties the knots oneself and crosses to the other shore to attain the immortals.
He causes all disciples to untie the knots and reach nirvÄá¹‡a.
Respecting and serving the Dharma King who has come, the mind is upright and the power of the Way is at peace.
The most victorious one is called the Buddha, his name is as renowned as the snow mountains.
Like a flower, pure and without doubt, one attains joy like approaching fragrance.
Ten thousand bodies are observed without weariness, his radiance is like the bright spiritual light.
The eight correct awakenings are attained by oneself, without separation and without defilement.
Love ends and the net of desire is broken, naturally receiving without a teacher,
I practice without a teacher's protection, my will is unique and without equal.
Accumulating one, I become a Buddha, from this I penetrate the path to sagehood,
The ultimate way has no coming or going, profound, subtle, and truly pure.
Not dying, not reborn, this is the place of nirvana,
This essential tranquility is unsurpassed, ultimately not experiencing suffering;
Although there are good places in the heavens, none are like nirvana,
My teacher, the Heaven of Heavens, the most honored one in the three realms.
With a body of thirty-two marks, six feet tall, with spiritual powers, roaming in the empty sky,
Perfumed by flowers, dispelling the five hindrances, uprooting the twelve faculties.
Not greedy for heavenly or worldly positions, the mind is pure, opening the Dharma gate,
The Buddha is the unsurpassed Dharma, the way governs the practice of purity and equality.
The Three Jewels in the later world, cutting off all desires and emotions,
Free from suffering, supreme, unconditioned, always joyful, comfortable, and at ease.
Always gathering before the Buddha, equally liberating all beings,
The vows and practices of the Buddha, diligently persevering for a hundred kalpas.
Great giving with the four immeasurable minds, the ten directions receiving vast kindness,
Upholding precepts pure and without defilement, compassionately protecting sentient beings.
Using wisdom to enter meditation, great compassion universally reading the sutras,
Always revered by the wise, the common ancestor of the sages.
Shakra and Brahma take him as their teacher, only then knowing the Buddha is supreme,
Difficult to encounter without compare, the most exalted with none above him.
Merits spreading far and wide, one should bow one's head in reverence,
Listen to me singing of the ten directions, abandoning hindrances and peacefully meditating.
Light penetrating and illuminating the seven heavens, virtue and fragrance surpassing sandalwood,
The divine and wondrous come from the highest heaven, praising and looking up to wanting to see the Honored One.
Shakra and Brahma equally respectful, bowing their heads wanting to ask questions,
Therefore, the Buddha crossed over the world, and his blessings were bestowed everywhere.
The teachings and precepts he spoke were clear in every place,
And he also spread the Dharma, and his disciples happily accepted and practiced it,
Causing devas, humans, ghosts, and dragons to respectfully accept and bow their heads in homage.
